awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Increased Scalability for Blockchains applied to Healthcare
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to drive down healthcare costs by enabling access to data through blockchain technology. The healthcare system is plagued by inefficiencies, many of which boil down to the inability to access the right data at the right time because of technological and business barriers. Leveraging blockchain for data access can drive an identified $100 billion in savings. However, while an estimated 40% of senior finance executives expect their firm to invest in blockchain over the next 2 years because of its transformational qualities, the transaction speed of blockchain needs to be improved. This project addresses this need, bringing a critical scaling innovation to Health Nexus - the open source, HIPAA-compatible blockchain.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to address several technical hurdles that will lead to successful commercialization. The project will deploy novel Graphene protocol for efficient propagation of completed transactions across the Health Nexus network. Graphene is a recent breakthrough in block propagation technology that requires a small fraction of network costs compared to existing technology, promising to improve performance of Health Nexus while lowering its costs. The project's research and development will seek to deploy Graphene on Health Nexus and quantify its performance in practice. Additional goals include designing and deploying fast methods for encoding blocks and selecting protocol parameters, methods for managing variation in the level of transaction synchronization among peers, and robust methods of recovery from failure. Early consensus identifies opportunity in supply chain management, drug distribution, and claims processing and billing, but there are innumerable amount of potential applications of blockchain in healthcare that cannot be predicted now - just as it would have been impossible to predict smartphones in early Internet days. The economic impact of bringing down healthcare cost has the potential to benefit millions of lives in ways we cannot imagine. This infrastructure is crucial as the foundation of blockchain innovation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In response to rising global demand as well as increasing costs, the healthcare system is looking for ways to drive efficiency while improving outcomes. To help fulfill this goal, many healthcare entities have begun to prioritize value- over volume-based care. One of the biggest impediments to widespread deployment of value-based care is fast, secure, and affordable access to healthcare data. In principle, blockchain technology is capable of delivering all these requirements, but currently few implementations can handle the unique requirements of the healthcare system. Health Nexus, a blockchain we developed, is designed specifically as a healthcare data sharing platform. It features a novel consensus mechanism that allows on-chain verification for HIPAA compatibility and other regulatory and security requirements. With plans for several other technological advances, Health Nexus is on its way to becoming a ubiquitous tool in the healthcare space.

In 2019, we received a Phase I award from the NSF STTR program to deploy Graphene, a cutting-edge algorithm for data delivery, on the Health Nexus blockchain. Blockchains encode transaction data in blocks, which must be disseminated throughout a globally diffuse peer-to-peer network. Graphene is a decentralized protocol that performs block transmission using a fraction of the bandwidth required by ordinary blocks. This compression of the block’s size is achieved by means of a novel combination of set reconciliation data structures. By reducing block size, Graphene enables Health Nexus to service larger blocks more quickly, which directly boosts service quality and commercial adoption. 

Graphene is a complex, probabilistic protocol having multiple stages, each with unique failure modes. Thus, in order to facilitate development, we partnered with professors at UMass Amherst who provided high-level guidance and data analysis. Beyond a basic implementation, the team completed four major tasks: 1) robust failure recovery, 2) quantification of performance improvement, 3) fast propagation parameter selection, and 4) management of variation in mempool synchronization.

By early 2020, a production implementation of Graphene was ready for the Health Nexus blockchain. Completion of Task 1 was perhaps the most difficult for the team because it required transition to practice of highly theoretical concepts. Members of the team leveraged their respective strengths and managed to achieve an overall failure rate below 2%. Completion of Task 2 revealed that Graphene reduced blocks to as little as 5% of their original size (see attached figure). Further analysis showed that Graphene compression will continue to improve as Health Nexus blocks begin to fill with more transactions. For Task 3, the team introduced heuristics in the Graphene algorithm to allow it to operate with lower CPU utilization, which is critical for widespread deployment over resource-constrained devices. Finally, Graphene relies on synchronicity of transaction information between peers in the blockchain, but network conditions often create some degree of variability. For Task 4, the team added another heuristic for tuning Graphene parameters to compensate for this variability. 

The development of Graphene technology constitutes a major leap for the Health Nexus blockchain toward the high transaction throughput required to process massive healthcare data. As a result, we are now better positioned for rapid growth in the healthcare space.
